Box 14965/115, Tehran, Iran Catalyst Research Group Petrochemical Research and Technology Company National Petrochemical Company (NPC-RT) P.O. Box 14965/115 Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation of copper and zinc hydroxycarbonates in the presence of various aluminum hydrous oxide sol preparation methods from sodium aluminate and aluminum nitrate as aluminum oxide sources. The catalysts were characterized at various stages of preparation by nitrogen adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, temperature programmed reduction and N2O chemisorption techniques. The TPR profiles of calcined precipitates were deconvoluted into three peaks which were assigned to the reduction of copper oxide species exhibiting different crystallite size and/or different interactions with zinc oxide. All catalysts were tested for methanol synthesis activity in a fixed-bed reactor under conditions similar to that of commercial operation (503K, 50bar and GHSV of 17250h−1), using H2, CO, and CO2 (80/12/8 molar ratio) mixture as the feed. The experimental results illustrated that the catalyst synthesized based on aluminum hydrous oxide sol prepared by peptization of aluminum hydroxide exhibited higher specific surface area, copper dispersion and catalytic activity for methanol synthesis. The catalysts thus prepared were shown to have less hydrotalcite-like phase, stronger interdispersion between Cu and ZnO and well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles with improved stability and activity in methanol synthesis from syngas. Keywords Methanol synthesis Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst TPR Colloidal solution Aluminum hydrous oxide sol 1 Introduction Methanol is produced on industrial scale from synthesis gas mixtures (CO/CO2/H2) over a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst at typical reaction conditions of 230–280°C and 50–100bar [1] with a worldwide production over 50 million metric tons per year [2]. Methanol is chiefly used as solvent and raw material. It is also of interest as a potential energy carrier in the future and a bulk chemical for fixation of the captured CO2 [3]. Industrial Cu/ZnO-based catalysts are prepared by co-precipitation method [4] which creates precursors with a definite stoichiometry capable of transformation into a porous and homogeneous aggregates of Cu and ZnO nanoparticles (NPs) component [5]. Nearly spherical Cu NPs of a size around 10nm and ZnO NPs which are arranged in an alternating manner forming porous aggregates with relatively large Cu exposed surface area of up to about 40m2g−1 are produced [2]. In recent years, the role of methanol as a basic chemical has strongly increased, and therefore further development of the ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis has become more important [6]. It is widely accepted that ZnO acts both as an electronic and structural promoter exhibiting a major influence on the catalytic activity, while alumina or other refractory oxides mainly increase the long-term stability as structural promoter of the ternary catalyst system [7]. Eliminating any of the constituting components severely reduces the performance of the catalyst system. Consequently, the interest in ternary CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 system as catalytic materials remains very high [8]. The precipitation conditions such as the concentration of initial solutions [9,10], precipitation temperature, pH of precipitation, addition of promoters [11–13] and the duration of aging of precursor precipitate play a significant role on the performance of the catalyst [14–16]. The activity and stability of the catalyst could be enhanced by using an appropriate support [17–19] and also by applying novel preparation methods [20–22]. Although many works has been done to improve the performance of methanol synthesis catalysts [23,24], the influence of using some novel sol and colloidal primary solutions as alternatives to true solutions to prepare the catalyst and their influence on catalytic activity, selectivity and stability have not yet been fully recognized. Aluminum hydrous oxide sols could be obtained by the addition of NH3 to the solution of an aluminum salt and also by peptization of an aluminum hydroxide precipitate [25,26]. This work focuses on using some novel primary solution based upon sol and colloidal systems for the preparation of the ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst and investigating their effect on the activity and stability of the catalyst for methanol synthesis. The catalysts were characterized by various relevant techniques and their catalytic performance was related to their structural and chemical properties. 2 Experimental 2.1 Precursor solutions preparation To prepare the catalysts, four different mixed copper, zinc and aluminum nitrate solutions were made according to the following procedures as summarized in Table 1 . The nominal Cu:Zn:Al molar ratios of all solutions were 60:30:10. 2.1.1 Copper, zinc nitrate and aluminum nitrate solutions (CZ_AN) Solutions of 1.0mol/L copper nitrate, 1.0mol/L zinc nitrate, (prepared separately by dissolving basic copper carbonate and zinc oxide in appropriate amount of nitric acid solution, respectively) and 1.0mol/L aluminum nitrate (AN) (prepared by dissolving aluminum nitrate nonahydrate in demineralized water) were mixed to obtain the ternary mixed metal nitrate true solution. 2.1.2 Copper, zinc nitrate and aluminum nitrate (AN) solution partially neutered by aqueous ammonia (“ammonium hydroxide”, AH) sol (CZ_AN+AH) First aluminum nitrate nonahydrate was dissolved in demineralized water to prepare 1.0mol/L solution. Then 2.5mol/L aqueous ammonia solution was added to achieve NH3(aq)/Al(NO3)3 molar ratio of 2.5. During addition of ammonia solution, aluminum hydroxide precipitate was observed which re-dissolved by completing addition of ammonia solution and a clear solution without precipitate was obtained. By this route, the (AN+AH) sol was prepared (Supplementary Fig. S1). Finally, the sol was added dropwise to 1.0mol/L copper nitrate and 1.0mol/L zinc nitrate mixed solution. 2.1.3 Copper, zinc nitrate solutions and sodium aluminate sol (CZ_SA) In this and in the following solutions, sodium aluminate (SA) was used as the source of aluminum in the catalysts. First sodium aluminate was dissolved in demineralized water to prepare 1.0mol/L solution and stirred for 20min to obtain the sodium aluminate sol (Supplementary Fig. S1). After that, appropriate amount of this solution was added dropwise to a mixture of 1.0mol/L copper nitrate and 1.0mol/L zinc nitrate solution. During addition of the sodium aluminate (a basic solution), small amount of white precipitate formed, most of which slowly re-dissolved, although a completely clear solution without precipitate was not obtained. 2.1.4 Copper, zinc nitrate solutions and acidified sodium aluminate sol (CZ_SA+NA) For preparation of the fourth precursor solution, first appropriate amount of 1.0mol/L sodium aluminate solution was prepared. Then 56% nitric acid (NA) was added to achieve HNO3/NaAlO2 molar ratio of 2.5. During addition of HNO3, gelation and formation of aluminum hydroxide precipitate was observed which re-dissolved by completing slow addition of nitric acid and heating. After that, aluminum hydrous oxide sol was formed (Supplementary Fig. S1). Finally, the sol was added dropwise to a mixture of 1.0mol/L copper nitrate and 1.0mol/L zinc nitrate solution. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts A series of ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst samples were prepared by co-precipitation method using the above primary solutions. The mixed copper, zinc and aluminum nitrate solutions (Table 1) and a solution of Na2CO3 as a precipitant were pumped into a stirred and heated glass reactor containing 250ml of demineralized water. During precipitation process, the metal nitrate solution was pumped continuously at a constant flow rate, while the temperature was controlled. The sodium carbonate solution was added with controlled flow rate to maintain a constant pH=6.5, monitored by a CONSORT R305 pH meter. The precipitation was stopped when 2.0l of metal nitrate solution was added. The resulting precursor was aged until a pH drop along with a color change from blue to green was observed. After aging, the precipitate (copper-zinc hydroxycarbonate precursors) was filtered, washed and then dried overnight at 105°C. The amount of residual sodium in the catalyst was checked by the analysis of decanted water from the last washing step for sodium content which was typically below 60ppm. Finally, the dried precipitate was calcined at 320 °C in a tubular furnace under air flow for 3.5h (3 °C/min). The catalyst names and their initial constituent mixed copper, zinc and aluminum solution are given in Table 1. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were carried out using a NOVA Quantachrome 2200 High-Speed Gas Sorption Analyzer, version 7.11. Before analysis, the samples were pre-treated under N2 gas flow at 150 °C for 1.5h. The isotherms were recorded at 77K. The BET surface area was calculated from multi-point adsorption data in the relative pressure interval from 0.05 to 0.25. The total micropore and mesopore volume (Vp ) was determined using the t-plot method [27]. The pore size distribution of the catalysts was determined by the BJH model applied to the adsorption branch of the isotherms. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of calcined catalysts were recorded on a BrukerD8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Ni filtered CuKα 1 radiation. The diffraction patterns were collected in the 2θ range from 10° to 70°. The crystallite size of CuO in calcined catalyst was estimated from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the basic CuO XRD peaks [2θ=38.8°, (111)+(200)] using the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)). (1) C r y s t a l l i t e S i z e ( n m ) = k λ β c o s θ where k is a constant which is 0.9 for spherical particles, λ X-ray wavelength (1.5406Å), and β is the FWHM in radians. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out in the range of 298–600K using a continuous flow apparatus comprising a U-shaped quartz micro-reactor. The fresh calcined precipitates were subjected to a stream of 6.0% H2/Ar mixture at 40ml/min and heating rate of 5K/min. The copper surface area of the reduced catalyst was determined by applying nitrous oxide chemisorption method according to 2Cu(s) +N2O(g) → Cu2O(s) +N2(g) assuming a surface atom density of 1.46×1019 atoms/m2 for copper [28,29]. The catalyst was first reduced using 6.0% H2 in argon and then cooled to chemisorption temperature (337K). A stream of N2O gas was fed into the reactor and the effluent gas was analyzed by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Nitrogen evolved by the reaction was calculated via peak area from the TCD signal. The crystallite size of Cu was also calculated from the specific surface area of copper with a spherical particle model using the following equation (Eq. (2)) [30,31]. (2) d C u ( m ) = 6 x C u ρ C u . S C u where xcu is the weight fraction of metallic copper in catalyst sample, ρCu the density of metallic copper (8960kgm−3) and SCu is the specific surface area of copper in m2 g−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a Zeiss EM10C microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 100kV. Samples for TEM imaging were prepared by crushing them followed by 10min sonication in ethanol. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Catalytic performance tests for methanol synthesis were carried out in a stainless steel, high pressure, tubular, fixed-bed reactor (I.D.=10mm) at 5.0MPa and 503K [11]. 1.00g of the catalysts within 16 and 25mesh size (mixed with the same mesh size of SiC in volume ratio of 1:3 of catalyst to SiC for uniform temperature distribution in the bed) was loaded in the reactor and reduced with diluted H2 (10% in N2) flow at 523K and atmospheric pressure for 14h before the syngas feed being introduced. The feed gas composition was 80 vol% H2, 12 vol% CO, and 8 vol% CO2 at flow of 250Nml/min. Under this condition, the space velocity was much higher than those of commercial-scale reactors so that the reactor effluent composition was far from that of thermodynamic equilibrium which made precise catalytic screening possible. The methanol, as well as, small amount of CH4, water and oxygenate byproducts and unreacted H2, CO, CO2 gases were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (Varian Star CP-3800) equipped with flame ionization and thermal conductivity detectors and two columns (capillary column HP-Plot Al2O3/Na2SO4, 50m, 0.53mm, 15μm and packed column Mol. sieve 13X (1/8 inch) Hysep Q (1/8 inch)). The effluent of the reactor was connected to the gas chromatograph by a heat traced line at 150°C to avoid condensation of the products. The main possible reactions during methanol synthesis are methanol synthesis path from CO2 (MS_CO2, i), water-gas shift reaction (WGS, ii), and methanol synthesis path from CO (MS_CO, iii) as follows: (i) MS _ CO 2 : CO 2 + 3H 2 = CH 3 OH + H 2 O Δ H 298 0 = − 49.5 kJ / mol (ii) WGS : CO + H 2 O = CO 2 +H 2 Δ H 298 0 = − 41.2 kJ / mol (iii) MS _ CO : CO + 2H 2 = CH 3 OH Δ H 298 0 = − 90.7 kJ / mol The approaches to equilibrium (η) of the above reactions over time were calculated based upon the concentration of effluent components according to the following equations: (3) η MS − CO 2 = ( CH 3 OH H 2 O ) / ( CO 2 H 2 3 ) ( CH 3 OH eq H 2 O eq ) / ( CO 2 eq H 2 eq 3 ) (4) η WGS = ( [ CO 2 ] [ H 2 ] ) / ( [ CO ] [ H 2 O ] ) ( [ CO 2 ] eq [ H 2 ] eq ) / ( [ CO ] eq [ H 2 O ] eq ) (5) η MS _ CO = ( [ CH 3 OH ] ) / ( [ CO ] [ H 2 ] 2 ) ( [ CH 3 OH ] eq ) / ( [ CO ] eq [ H 2 ] eq 2 ) The rate of methanol production and activity of the catalysts was calculated from the space time yield during reaction. The turn over frequency (TOF) defined as methanol molecules produced per unit surface copper atom per second [32] was calculated with the assumption that each surface copper atom acted as an active site, being related to specific surface area of copper; using the following equation (Eq. (6)) [33]. (6) T O F ( m o l c u l e M e O H . s − 1 s i t e − 1 ) = R M e O H × N A S C u × n s where RMeOH is methanol production rate in molg−1 s−1, NA the Avogadro number, ns copper surface atom density equal to 1.46×1019 atoms/m2 and SCu is same as in Eq. (2). The selectivity was determined based on carbon atom by using the FID chromatograms. The stability of the methanol productivity over time was evaluated based upon the methanol signal from the FID detector. Second order independent deactivation rate laws were fitted according to the general power law expression (GPLE) with m = 2 as follows [34,35]: (7) ( 1 a − a e q ) − ( 1 1 − a e q ) = k d , 2 × t in which a is catalyst activity defined as methanol production rate on the catalyst that has been used for a time t to that on the fresh catalyst, aeq asymptotic activity as t → ∞ and kd,2 is the second-order deactivation constant. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nitrogen adsorption and desorption In precipitation route, the precursor solution generates the primary particles which agglomerate and form a porous structure [36]. Fig. 1 shows the N2-physisorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distributions. As judged from the shape of the isotherms and hystereses, the isotherms of all samples were of type IV and the pores of all catalysts were in mesopores range (2nm<pore diameter<50nm). Since condensation occurred at relatively high pressure (P/P 0 =0.75), the catalysts had relatively large cavities (mesopores). For all samples, the H1 type hysteresis (according to IUPAC classification [37]) was observed. This type is characteristic of solids consisting of particles crossed by nearly cylindrical channels or made by aggregates of spheroidal particles in which pores have uniform size and shape. As can be seen in Fig. 1a, for samples prepared based on sol formation (CZ_AN+AH, CZ_SA and CZ_SA+NA), the adsorption volumes increased compared to that of CZ_AN reference catalyst being prepared by conventional (true solution) path. Fig. 1b shows the surface of mesopore walls as function of pore size. In BJH curves of catalysts made via sol formation (CZ_AN+AH, CZ_SA and CZ_SA+NA) two distinct peaks can be observed (i.e., bimodal pore size distribution), whereas virtually one peak is detected in CZ_AN reference catalyst. The first peak showed relatively low-intensity band in the pore diameter range of 2–5nm and a second one showed a broad pore size band in the range 5–64nm. The physicochemical properties and some textural characteristics of the prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . For samples prepared based on sol formation, the total pore volumes, and also average pore diameters exhibited a remarkable increase, however, no appreciable enhancement was observed in BET surface areas of the samples. These catalysts also showed a significant micropore contribution. For CZ_SA+NA sample, the use of aluminum hydrous oxide sol led to a marked increase in the BET surface area. The preparation not involved aluminum hydrous oxide sol led to comparatively lower specific surface area. This could be due to the increased ionic strength of the electrolyte which decreased the thickness of the diffuse part of double layer and the repulsion between the particles, thereby favored aggregation according to the DLVO theory and the Stern model. Furthermore, the solubility of dissolved aluminum species was exceeded resulting in deposition of aluminum species over particle surface or at the contact points of the aggregated particles and formation of a neck between the particles, which lowered the specific surface area [25]. 3.2 X-Ray diffraction and N2O chemisorption The X-ray diffractograms of the catalyst precursors and calcined catalysts before and after the methanol synthesis test runs are presented in Fig. 2 a–c, respectively. All observed peaks correspond to CuO, Cu and ZnO in the calcined catalysts. The XRD patterns of the precursors after precipitation and drying, before calcination, are shown in Fig. 2a. The reflections set at 2θ values of 11.7, 23.7°, 2θ values of 17.4, 24.1°, 2θ values of 17.2, 23.7° and 2θ values of 24.0, 34.3° were assigned to crystalline hydrotalcite [(Cu,Zn)6Al2(OH)16CO3], malachite [Cu2(OH)2CO3] and zincian malachite [(Cu,Zn)2CO3(OH)2] and aurichalcite [(Cu,Zn)5(CO3)2(OH)6] phases, respectively. The zincian malachite (ZM) phase can be derived from the malachite crystal structure by substituting some of the Cu2+ ions with Zn2+. Upon substitution of Cu with Zn the structure slightly contracts in an anisotropic manner leading to a shift of the d ( 20 1 ¯ ) position (vertical line in Fig. 2a) [38–41] which scales linearly with the amount of incorporated zinc into the ZM lattice. This change is observed for our samples as well (Table 2). For the CZ_AN reference sample, the d ( 20 1 ¯ ) value of 2.786Å corresponded to ca. 78% Cu in cationic positions (for calculation method refer to Supplementary S5). A d ( 20 1 ¯ ) value of 2.758Å, as observed for the CZ_SA+NA corresponded to 71% Cu in cationic positions. This showed a higher amount of Cu substitution by Zn in the latter; which could be achieved by using alumina hydrous oxide sol. According to the intensity of diffracted line at 2θ value of 11.7° it was observed that the precursors of sodium aluminate route catalysts (CZ_SA and CZ_SA+NA) had a smaller fraction of a hydrotalcite-like phase compared to other catalysts presumably because aluminum hydroxide sol no longer reacted with copper and zinc phases to form hydrotalcite. The hydrotalcite phase forms a Cu/ZnO phase after calcination and reduction exhibiting relatively high stability but low activity. Accordingly, the fractions of malachite and ZM phases in the CZ_SA+NA precursor were higher compared to other catalysts. Therefore, it could be concluded that the precursor of CZ_SA+NA catalyst had more ZM phase arisen from malachite in which a part of Cu atoms was substituted by Zn. The CuO/ZnO resulted from malachite in the calcined catalyst favored the formation of CuO crystallites and metallic Cu nanoparticles during reduction wherein the particles were smaller than the particles derived from pure Cu phase [9]. During thermal treatment of ZM, a well dispersed mixed CuO and ZnO phase is formed which is very active because of interdispersion of copper and zinc [42] but it is not so stable. Furthermore, as many authors illustrated, malachite and ZM are ideal precursor for methanol synthesis catalyst and the presence of more ZM phase in catalyst precursors can promote the activity of the catalyst [43–45]. In the other words, formation of large quantity of (Cu,Zn)2CO3(OH)2 can cause the formation of CuO-ZnO solid-solution which could be the active phase for the methanol synthesis [15,46]. Fig. 2b shows the X-ray diffraction profiles of the calcined samples prepared from different initial solutions. The reflections at 2θ values of 35.6 and 38.7° and 2θ values of 31.8, and 34.5° accounts for the presence of crystalline domains of CuO and ZnO, respectively [47]. It should be noted that the peaks assigned to CuO and ZnO were relatively weak, and there were no peaks that could be attributed to Al2O3 implying that CuO and ZnO were meagerly crystallized while Al2O3 existed in an amorphous state. It should be noted that according to CuO JCPDS card, the intensity of (200) peak is about 27% that of (111) peak, therefore, the former would not have a significant effect on FWHM of (111) peak. As a consequence, it was assumed that the FWHM of (111) peak is unaffected by (200) peak. The intensity of the reflections attributed to CuO phase increased for CZ_AN+AH and CZ_SA catalysts and decreased for CZ_SA+NA catalyst in the diffractograms of the samples. In the case of the latter, even some diffraction peaks disappeared. The average crystallite sizes of the copper oxide (in fresh catalyst) and copper (in used catalyst) were determined from the Scherrer equation (Table 2). The average CuO size ranged from 4.4nm for the case of CZ_SA+NA to 8.2nm for CZ_SA. In line with the above observation, the average CuO crystallite size increased by using a combination of aluminum nitrate and ammonia, and sodium aluminate (as sources of aluminum oxide), instead of aluminum nitrate, in CZ_AN+AH and CZ_SA samples, respectively. However, using aluminum hydrous oxide sol by adding nitric acids to sodium aluminate in CZ_SA+NA sample resulted in a decrease in CuO crystallite size. The size of CuO crystallites in CZ_AN sample was ca. 6.1nm, and slightly decreased to ca. 4.4nm in the samples utilizing aluminum hydrous oxide sol. For CZ_SA+NA sample no significant diffraction peaks to be ascribed to Cu-containing phases were detected. In the other words, CZ_SA+NA had the widest diffraction peaks before reactor testing; therefore, its primary crystallite size was smaller than that of other samples. This observation suggested that the dispersion of the CuO domains increased for this catalyst due to the structural changes by using of aluminum hydrous oxide sol which increased the resistance of CuO to sintering during the calcination and thermal treatment. Fig. 2c shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the reduced and used samples. After catalytic tests, sharper diffraction peaks were observed because of the increased crystallite sizes due to sintering during the test run. The main diffraction peaks observed at 2θ of 43.3 and 50.5° were attributed to metallic Cu. Surprisingly, the peaks assigned to CuO were also observed in reduced CZ_SA+NA sample diffractogram. It seems to be due to the small crystallite size and large copper surface area in this sample, promoting partial re-oxidization of Cu° crystallites to CuO during discharging of micro-reactor and XRD operation test, which could not be completely avoided. The Cu° crystallite size for the used samples was also determined using the Scherrer equation. As can be seen in Table 2, for CZ_SA+NA sample, the average Cu° crystallite size as well as its growth were minimal compared to other catalysts. Also, the XRD patterns (Fig. 2c) clearly showed that peak sharpening for this catalyst was lowest and therefore it undergone minimum crystallite growth and, accordingly, it was expected to be most stable catalyst. It should be mentioned that copper crystallite growth was greatest for CZ_AN catalyst. Therefore, it could be concluded that catalyst preparation using true solutions of aluminum precursor would not lead to catalysts with high stability. Based on the N2O chemisorption results, the copper specific surface area (and also Cu dispersion) of the catalysts decreased upon using combination of aluminum nitrate and ammonia (CZ_AN+AH sample) and also sodium aluminate (CZ_SA sample) as sources of aluminum. However, it significantly increased by using aluminum hydrous oxide sol (CZ_SA+NA sample). Therefore, it is expected that the CZ_SA+NA sample can provide more catalytically active sites with high dispersion and high exposed copper surface area. TEM images of CZ_SA+NA catalyst prepared from aluminum hydrous oxide sol precursor are shown in Fig. 3 . The micrographs demonstrated nano-structured CuO and ZnO particles ranging from 3 to 8nm. These results are in good agreement with the crystallite size calculated from copper specific surface area and also with that estimated from CuO XRD peaks using Scherrer equation (Table 2). Since the sol particles have rod-like shapes [25], filamentous needle fiber morphology could form. The size of the thin needles was ca. 10×150nm. Similar morphology has been reported previously for the catalyst precursor though with larger sizes by Behrens [38]. Such morphology can be cited as an ideal catalyst structure. 3.3 Catalyst reduction Calcination of hydroxycarbonate precipitates converts them to CuO and ZnO oxides the former of which is subsequently reduced by H2 to Cu. According to the literature, the H2 TPR profiles of the catalysts have two peaks, a low temperature and a higher temperature one corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed and bulky CuO species, respectively [43,48–54]. Behrens et al., proposed the reduction of CuO proceeds in two steps mechanism through CuI intermediate [55]. It has been also reported that CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 reduction could proceed in three steps [45,56–58]. The TPR profiles of the prepared catalysts are depicted in Fig. 4 . All curves were deconvoluted into three reduction peaks by a Gaussian-type function. The deconvoluted plots showed that all samples were actually reduced in three steps. In the temperature range of 160–200°C a low-intensity band can be seen (low temperature peak). In the range of 190–220°C, there is a sharp reduction band of high-intensity (medium temperature peak), whereas at 210–240°C a high-temperature band is observed (high temperature peak). The TPR profiles with different heating rates of the CZ_SA sample are shown in Figs. S3 and S4 in the Supplementary information. At low heating rate, the shoulders in the left and right sides of the profile are more prominent. The existing interaction between the phases may have an influence on the enhanced reducibility of copper. Fierro and coworkers [50] revealed that ZnO beside being a dispersive agent, likely plays the role of H2 activator, thereby enhancing the reduction of copper. It has been demonstrated that H2 activation and spill-over would be improved by the extended contact area between CuO and ZnO particles resulting in a promoting effect of the copper reduction by ZnO. Surface and CuO species interacting with the ZnO particles are believed to be more reactive. A previous paper [59] also showed that strong interaction of copper at the ZnO surface occurs, indicating that the CuO bonding in the catalysts was more covalent than that in pure CuO. As Cu dispersion is improved, a larger fraction of the total copper may be in intimate contact with the surface of ZnO particles resulting in higher interaction. Deconvolution of TPR profiles into three distinct peaks showed that, indeed, copper oxide species could be divided into three categories in terms of ease of H2 access and ease of reducibility. Different interpretations could be suggested to explain three reduction peaks observed in the TPR profiles. They could be assigned, for instance, to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO particles, large particles with ZnO contact and large particles without ZnO contact. Assigning to small copper crystallites, reduction of CuII to CuI and CuI to Cu° in larger crystallites is another possibility. Still another possibility is that the first reduction peak belonged to the copper oxide of the surface layer (surface CuO) which was in direct contact with ZnO species, the second reduction peak corresponded to an intermediate layer (bulk-intermediate CuO) being indirectly influenced by ZnO due to several atomic layer distance, whereas the third peak fitted to reduction of core layer of copper oxide (bulk-core CuO). Based on this model, the thickness of each hypothetical layer could be estimated. The thickness of the surface and intermediate layers, therefore, should be governed mostly by CuO-ZnO interaction not by particle size. Table 3 illustrates that the thickness of surface and intermediate layers were approximately the same in all samples irrespective of CuO particle size. Obviously, if the crystallite size was very small, reduction could only occur in two stages because there was no copper oxide species with difficult reducibility. As shown in Table 3, CZ_SA+NA catalyst had the smallest crystallite sizes and hence possessed the largest proportion of copper surface atoms. Therefore, it showed the largest peak for reduction of surface atoms (low temperature peak). In case of CZ_SA catalyst, it possessed the largest crystallite size and lower proportion of copper surface atoms and, therefore, the smallest first reduction peak was observed for this catalyst. Considering the third reduction peak (high temperature peak) for the CZ_SA+NA catalyst, this reduction peak was very small because the catalyst had smallest CuO crystallites which resulted in a very small fraction of copper atoms being located at the core section where there was no interaction with ZnO. The remaining catalysts had relatively larger crystallites sizes so their core-copper atoms were considerable; therefore, the areas under of their third peaks were more prominent. The preparations by aluminum hydrous oxides sols resulted in a shift of the reduction bands toward lower temperatures. The shift in reduction curve for such catalysts might also be due to enlarging of the first peak and shrinking the second and third peaks as a consequence of growth of crystallite size. Therefore, the reduction process of large crystallite catalysts proceeded at higher temperatures and the intensity of reduction bands might decrease slightly. Larger CuO crystallites need higher reduction temperatures. The increase in TPR peak temperature with CuO crystallite size could be attributed to the increase of bulk to surface CuO peak ratios, with the latter needed higher reduction temperature as mentioned previously. As a consequence, achieving smaller crystallite size during precipitation and aging is critical to obtain catalysts with high performance. This CuO-ZnO interaction model is further supported by recent observations of Willinger et al. [60] and Behrens et al. [40] who provided evidence that CuO particles are surrounded by graphite-like or spherical ZnO particles, respectively. The CuO and Cu crystallite size are given in Table 2. The increase in crystallite size during the reduction of nano-sized Cu/ZnO catalysts indicated a pronounced sintering of copper particles. 3.4 Catalyst performance results in methanol synthesis The activity of the synthesized Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts and a commercial reference catalyst were evaluated under relevant industrial methanol synthesis conditions. Since the focus of our study was also on catalyst stability, the catalytic tests were performed at a rather high space velocity of 17250h−1 to achieve sufficient departure from equilibrium and to be able to monitor catalyst deactivation within laboratory time scales. 3.4.1 Initial catalytic performance The initial catalyst mass-specific methanol production rates for all the studied catalysts ranged from 40 to 55mol k g cat − 1 h − 1 being comparable to, and higher up to 30% than, that for the reference commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 5 ). Over Cu/Zn/Al2O3 catalysts prepared with different initial sol formation procedures, for which the copper metal surface area was determined (Table 2), the initial catalytic activity was normalized per surface Cu atom. All catalysts showed fairly constant TOF or initial surface-specific activity of (1.55±0.1)×10−2 moleculeMeOH.site−1 s−1 (Fig. 7). Therefore, differences in catalyst mass-specific initial rate seem to be exclusively due to variations in the exposed Cu surface area, rather than to differences in the intrinsic site activity. Although N2O chemisorption is widely used for measuring Cu surface area, it may give over-estimate results when reduced ZnO species is present which might have important consequences in TOF values [61]. However, in present work the BET surface areas were typically three-fold larger than corresponding Cu surface areas (Table 2), rendering this possibility unlikely. Furthermore, the Cu (based on N2O chemisorptions) and corresponding CuO (based on XRD) crystallite diameters in Table 2 are close and consistent. Fig. 5 illustrates the initial methanol production rate and selectivity, as well as, the methanol production rate after 120h on stream versus preparation methods of the catalysts. The CZ_AN catalyst prepared by co-precipitation from mixed true solutions under optimized and controlled conditions exhibited slightly better performance than the commercial catalyst. The CZ_SA catalyst with sodium aluminate as the source of aluminum consumed about 50% lower sodium carbonate during precipitation compared to other catalysts because sodium aluminate solution is inherently strongly basic. Therefore its addition to mixed copper and zinc nitrates solution increases the pH of primary metals nitrates solution. Lower consumption of sodium carbonate resulted in lower availability of CO3 2−ions, and as a consequence, it caused lower incorporation of this ion in the structure of the initial hydroxycarbonate precipitate and, therefore, the degradation of morphology after heat treatment. The decreased BET and specific copper surface areas of this catalyst (Table 2) proves the above mentioned events and led to catalyst with lower activity as well. In the case of CZ_AN+AH catalyst, the addition of aqueous ammonia to the aluminum nitrate (to prepare aluminum hydrous oxide sol) resulted in an undesirable side effect; that is, the formation of water-soluble [Cu(NH3)4(H2O)2]2+ complex through which a part of the copper ion remained in solution and did not participate in catalyst formation. Therefore, the copper content in the catalyst as well as the exposed copper surface and, consequently, the activity reduced (Table 2). In CZ_SA+NA catalyst, resulted from alumina hydrous oxide sol, the decrease in the particle sizes and increase in the levels of exposed copper might be due to copper crystallites trapped within the structure of the network. 3.4.2 Approach to equilibrium Since several equilibrium-limited reactions occur simultaneously during methanol synthesis, the approaches to equilibrium analysis could give useful information on their importance and sequences [30,62]. The calculated values of approach to equilibrium (η) for the three main methanol synthesis reactions are presented in Fig. 6 a and b. The reactions involved were previously mentioned as Reactions [(i), (ii) and (iii)]. It should be noted that MS_CO reaction is actually a linear combination of MS_CO2 and WGS reactions. Methanol can be produced by MS_CO2 reaction as well as by the MS_CO reaction therewith the consumed CO2 by MS_CO2 reaction can be supplied by WGS reaction. The figures show that all reactions were slowed-down by catalyst deactivation. The largest η was observed for WGS reaction implying that it was comparatively fast and rapidly equilibrated. This is especially critical for mechanisms considering CO2 as source carbon in methanol synthesis from CO/H2 mixture. As can be seen in Fig. 6a and b, the steady values of η for MS_CO2 reaction was about 0.2 while, that for MS_CO reaction was about 0.1 indicating that the reaction rate for the MS_CO2 reaction is significantly larger than MS_CO reaction. The η values for methanol synthesis reactions illustrate firstly, that MS_CO2 reaction proceeds and produces water which causes WGS reaction occurs consequently. Unlike many references that stated the RWGS reaction is the main route of methanol synthesis [63], actually WGS reaction occurs. Studt et al. [64] recently obtained similar results through a mechanistic study of CO and CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over Cu-based catalysts. They found, for example, that under integral reaction conditions CO and water (produced by CO2 hydrogenation) are converted to CO2 (and hydrogen) by the water–gas-shift reaction, which is fast compared to methanol synthesis on Cu-based catalysts and, therefore, equilibrates. Their kinetic model predicts that despite the low CO2 hydrogenation rate, the carbon source gradually changes from CO to CO2 with increasing CO2 concentration in the feed because of the strong site-blocking effect of formate on CO hydrogenation. 3.4.3 Catalyst stability The regression of the normalized methanol activity versus time on stream with Eq. (7) is depicted in Fig. 7 . Under the applied reaction conditions, the catalytic activities dropped 35–60% in the first 120h on stream with similar deactivation curves were obtained for CZ_SA and CZ_AN+AH catalysts. Previous studies revealed that catalyst deactivation correlates with Cu particle growth [18], although it does not fully account for the observed activity decay. This suggests that particle growth brings about additional secondary effects on the catalytic activity, which might be explained by a deterioration of Cu interaction with the Zn and Al species. The GPLE has been extensively used to describe experimental catalyst deactivation by metal particle growth. Values of rate constants (kd,2 ) are important to know how fast sintering occurs and values of aeq show how far the loss of surface area and deactivation of catalyst would progress for a given set of catalyst and operating variables. In this study Eq. (7) (GPLE with m =2) was also used to fit the experimental deactivation curves for prepared catalysts. The exponent m is assumed to be related to the growth mechanism. An exponent m of 2 has been previously attributed to growth mechanisms such as Ostwald ripening mediated by gas-phase atom transport and particle migration–coalescence for which the particle coalescence events are rate-limiting [65]. In order to consistently compare the deactivation rates for different catalysts, all the deactivation data were fitted to the linearized integral form of the second-order decay law (Eq. (7)) and the corresponding deactivation rate constants (kd,2 ) and equilibrium activity (aeq ) were determined. The resulting second-order deactivation rate constants and equilibrium activities for all samples are also given in Fig. 7. For CZ_AN+AH and CZ_SA+NA catalysts the deactivation rate constants were smaller than those of other catalysts, while the numerical value of aeq for CZ_SA+NA was maximum. It showed that using alumina hydroxyl oxide sol had dual positive effects on both deactivation rate constants and asymptotic activity. The initial methanol production rate, deactivation rate constants (kd,2 ) and also equilibrium activity (aeq ) were least desirable for CZ_SA catalyst. It may be due to low sodium carbonate consumption during its preparation compared to other catalysts because of the relatively high pH value of initial mixture of metal nitrates solution. Precursor XRD patterns for this catalyst showed low crystallinity along with unfavorable structure and morphology. The favorable performance results (lower deactivation rate constants, higher equilibrium activity and higher initial methanol production rate) for CZ_SA+NA resulted from using aluminum hydrous oxide sol in primary solution were ascribed to maximal interparticle spacings afforded by the high Cu dispersion during preparation by this route. This observation also might relate to differences in the dominant growth mechanism. The lower value of deactivation rate constant for CZ_SA+NA showed aluminum hydrous oxide sol suppressed the coalescence of the copper crystallites after reduction. Fichtl et al. [66] also used independent mechanism with simple power law expressions (SPLE) to express kinetics of catalyst deactivation. They obtained third and fourth order kinetics with rate constants (initial deactivation rates) ranging from 5×10−4 to 4×10−3 h−1. They defined the “relative activity” in their calculations as the ratio of COx conversion to its initial value (at t =0) which, in addition to reaction rates, depends on reactor performance as well. Because of different rate laws employed, the kinetic parameters could not be directly compared. However, the initial deactivation rates of our catalysts were much larger (0.02–0.05h−1) which could be, in part, due to different definition for catalyst activity. Indeed, due to crucial influence of the synthesis route on the catalytic properties which is also termed the “chemical memory”, it seems that Al2O3 particles obtained from aluminum hydrous oxide sol during calcination act as network altitudes on the catalyst surface, between which the copper oxide crystallites and copper crystallites (in reduced state) are located so to express an “energy concave”. The zinc oxide also acts to stabilize the catalyst as it forms part of the netlike aluminum oxide structure on the surface of the catalyst contributing to confinement coalescence of the Cu-crystallites after reduction. Hence, the greater stability is most likely due to restricted crystallites migration which brings about higher copper metal dispersion and partitioning them into compartments and so limits their growth by particle coalescence. 4 Conclusions It was found that the preparation method of the initial aluminum precursor solution has a strong effect on the performance of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by co-precipitation in methanol synthesis due to the “chemical memory”. Aluminum hydrous oxide sol can be successfully used as an alternative to true aluminum salt solution in preparation of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts. The highest methanol productivity and more durable activity can be achieved for the catalyst prepared from acidified sodium aluminate in which the aluminum hydroxide oxide sol is formed by peptization of aluminum hydroxide. The great productivity of catalysts obtained by these methods is interrelated with its relatively high BET and metallic Cu surface areas and smaller size of CuO nanoparticles. The TPR profiles of CuO species of the catalysts can be deconvoluted to three peaks which could be assigned to, for example, reduction of highly dispersed CuO particles, large particles with ZnO contact and large particles without ZnO contact. A novel possible interpretation is assigning the peaks to the reduction of surface copper species in intimate contact with zinc oxide and intermediate and core copper oxide species which have little and no interaction with zinc oxide, respectively. This model is in agreement with the calculated thickness of the respective layers for different samples. According to approach to equilibrium values, WGS reaction occurs practically in methanol synthesis pathway rather than RWGS reaction and the reaction rate for methanol synthesis from CO2 is significantly larger than that from CO. coredata.dc:description: Ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation of copper and zinc hydroxycarbonates in the presence of various aluminum hydrous oxide sol preparation methods from sodium aluminate and aluminum nitrate as aluminum oxide sources. The catalysts were characterized at various stages of preparation by nitrogen adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, temperature programmed reduction and N2O chemisorption techniques. The TPR profiles of calcined precipitates were deconvoluted into three peaks which were assigned to the reduction of copper oxide species exhibiting different crystallite size and/or different interactions with zinc oxide. All catalysts were tested for methanol synthesis activity in a fixed-bed reactor under conditions similar to that of commercial operation (503K, 50bar and GHSV of 17250h−1), using H2, CO, and CO2 (80/12/8 molar ratio) mixture as the feed. The experimental results illustrated that the catalyst synthesized based on aluminum hydrous oxide sol prepared by peptization of aluminum hydroxide exhibited higher specific surface area, copper dispersion and catalytic activity for methanol synthesis. The catalysts thus prepared were shown to have less hydrotalcite-like phase, stronger interdispersion between Cu and ZnO and well-dispersed Cu nanoparticles with improved stability and activity in methanol synthesis from syngas.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of high performance nano-sized Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 methanol synthesis catalyst via aluminum hydrous oxide sol
